values: Soldiers will be briefed understand the entire range to include but not limited to adjacent units, targets and range fans
All targets are within the maneuver box and all engagements would fire in between the range fans
Teams will conduct blank iteration before conducting a life iteration.
Teams will re-execute blank iteration if soldiers do not clearly understand the exercise.

Soldiers obey the 4 rules of weapons safety at all times: treat every weapon as if it was loaded, keep weapon on safe until you intend to fire, keep finger off the trigger until ready to fire, know your target and what is behind it.
TEWT with all Team Leaders Range Safety Brief

subtasks.hazard: Soldiers maneuvering into SDZs of base of fire

values: Soldiers obey the 4 rules of weapons safety at all times: treat every weapon as if it was loaded, keep weapon on safe until you intend to fire, keep finger off the trigger until ready to fire, know your target and what is behind it.
Soldiers will bound for 3-5 seconds at a time 25m and will be controlled by the safeties.
No soldier will be within 40 degrees to the left and right of each firer.
There will be 2 safeties present for each 4 man Team.
Range Safeties will closely monitor bounding and call cease fire if needed

subtasks.hazard: Weapon Safety Posture for non-executing teams

values: Range Safety will be last off the range and issue the command for the next team to move to WSP "RED" when the range has been cleared from all previous firers and is ready to begin the next iteration.
Beachmaster will ensure that next team remains "GREEN" while waiting on "On Deck"
Safeties will give the soldiers the command to engage inside building

subtasks.hazard: Negligent Discharge or Weapon Malfunction Causing Bodily Harm

values: required PPE while on the range. To include front and side plates
Lane safeties and the OIC / RSO will ensure weapon systems are properly oriented downrange and operating in a safe manner at all times.
Weapons will be visual cleared by RSO following completion of the lane.
Weapons will be pointed downrange at all times away from personnel when loaded.
A Medic will be on standby located in the FLA with the vehicle crew co-located inside.
PMI Conduct safety brief prior to each phase Conduct clearing procedure in accordance with TM
Range orientation brief during daily range safety brief by RSO.
Range fans clearly marked and visible.
Weapon systems properly cleared before leaving the firing line.
Range fans identified by each crew prior to execution.
Prior to execution crews will receive a brief on the approved SDZ of each maneuver box and battle position.
Range orientation brief from the OIC/RSO prior to training. Crew identify range fans before each iteration.
Range orientation brief from the OIC/RSO prior to training. Crew identify range fans before each iteration.
Brief all participants to immediately report potential unauthorized access on the Range or in the live fire area to the OIC and RSO.
Range Safety Brief Task to Troops OIC/RSO Supervision

subtasks.hazard: Combustions / Fire at the ammo point

values: least two fire extinguishers on hand.
No smoking withing 50m of ammo point
Ammo will be stored in accordance with QUASAS Range OPS, and 2CR policy.
Ammo point inspected by RSO and OIC
Medics and CLS qualified personnel on site with CLS bag and MEDEV AC vehicle.
Proper placement of MEDEVAC vehicle during range operations.
Know the location of the AXP.
The FLA personnel will conduct RXLs to and from the day/night iterations to the AXPs prior to the iterations beginning.
Soldiers will use 3 points of contact while operating on top of Strykers.
When moving in a wheeled vehicle, Soldiers will wear seat belts and gunner restraints at all times.
All Soldiers on the range will wear proper PPE to include gloves, eye pro, ear pro, and body armor.
RSO inspects MEDEVAC vehicle prior to range operations. RSO briefs MEDEVAC vehicle staging safety brief. On site Medics briefed CASEVAC procedures and route.
Use of snow chains when snow and ice are on the ground.
Reduce vehicle speed based on road condition
Use of ground guides and chem lights during poor visibility due to weather.
If lightning is in the immediate area all personnel will move to the nearest grounded hard stand structure or spread out in low ground away from all equipment.
Brief inclement weather condition and safety measures during safety brief
OIC will monitor temperature and humidity of ground surface.
Verify fire danger posted by Range Operation daily.
Identify fire team and have appropriate FFE on-hand and ready.
OIC will place range in "DRY" status and notify Range Operation.
Cold weather clothing included on the Range packing list.
Soldiers will download all unspent ammo and be inspected before being issued ammo for the next iteration
Ammo NCOIC will monitor 2 different ammo points separated by c-wire
Ammo NCOIC will be senior E5 or E6

subtask.name: MOVEMENT TO, FROM, AND ON TRAINING SITE

values: vehicle PMCS prior to movement, all Soldier's will adhere to posted speed limit signs, drive
Ground guides will be used when maneuvering all vehicles onto the range or motorpool
Sleeping areas will be marked with Chem lights and engineer tape. Soldiers will not sleep next to any vehicle.
Use of proper hand and arm signals when maneuvering all vehicles.
Ramp briefs will be conducted prior to SP.
Conduct safety brief at each phase, addressing: speed, route, and vehicle safety

subtask.name: MOVEMENT TO, FROM, AND ON TRAINING SITE

values: Brief crews on procedures during limited visibility conditions.
Soldiers will use NODs, DVEs, and RWS FLIR during limited visibility and night time operations.
White light will be use when conducting admin moves.
Ground guides will be used during times of degraded visibility.
PCCs and PCIs Brief limited visibility conditions during safety brief.

draw.overall_supervision_plan: This is a living document. Newly identified risks will be recorded and mitigated accordingly and risk acceptance will be approved at the appropriate level.The OIC, RSO, and range leadership will conduct a range safety brief prior to all live fire training. The OIC and RSO are overall responsible for safety. However, team leaders, squad leaders, and safeties have the responsibility to be actively engaged in range activities and Soldier actions so as to mitigate risk at the lowest level possible and ensure overall safety for the training event. Range OIC all first line supervisors are responsible for all actions on the range. Vehicle movement will be restricted on the range once Soldiers are dismounted. All vehicles will be ground guided and parked in designated area. Troops are briefed on the route, travel speed, trail distance, fire drills, roll over drills, communication plan and vehicle safety prior to SP. Medic and CASEVAC Vehicle (Arranged by Range OIC) are on sight. All entry points to range are guarded at all times and guards have communications with OIC or NCOIC.
